Melo, Francisco Manuel de. Obras Métricas de Don Francisco Manuel al Sereníssimo Señor Infante Don Pedro. León de Francia (Lyon). Horacio Boechat & George Remeus. 1665.
Centro de Estudos de Teatro, Universidade de Lisboa
Melo, Francisco Manuel de. O Fidalgo Aprendiz. Online edition by José Camões. CET-UL. http://www.fl.ul.pt/cet-publicacoes/cet-edicoes-onlibe/cet-pecas/727-pecas-sec-xvi

w.comment: 'Ressio' is a variant pronunciation of 'Rossio', famous square in Lisbon
'Rescão' is variant pronunciation of 'rascão', a rascal.
Vem-me ele ensinar a mim. (CET-UL edition)
Same as 'pé-de-xibão' (chibau < from Gascon horse) - an Old Portuguese dance style.
Italics not present in the original.
A potion used to prepare cosmetics.
Probably means that it is difficult to take money from the courtisans that used to please Brites.
Spanish name for the parting of hair, or for each one of the parted sides.
Plural of "dom", analogically related to the Latin form.
This form is maintained for the pun with the arcaic form 'trebelhar', meaning "brincar".
The character sings the first verses of "Silvana", a traditional novel from the Iberian Peninsula. From the next verse we can infer that this piece of work is considered Portuguese, not Spanish.
Or "sino de recolher" - reference to a bell that used to be rung from 8 to 9 pm, or from 9 to 10 pm, depending on the time of the year.
Old skirt, with folds around the waist.
To give out something by ruinous selling, or failure in a game.
According to Mário Fiuza's edition (1978), the word 'compricurtos' is a hapax (cumpre+curtos) and the expression means that he will keep his word (regarding small promises made).
May be either someone from Flanders, or any foreigner, from a generalization of that designation.
Sort of clothing of old security guards in Minho.
A sword used by a Justice official, auxiliary to the alcaide and the meirinho, of higher status.
A mask hiding part of the face.
"ração" (in verse 21 from 'Primeira jornada', Afonso says his boss promised to give him 2.100 réis "a seco", i.e., without meal).
= "passai a pente fino" (do not leave anything with him).
Used as a compliment to Isabel's skilfulness.
Sort of leather vest, used by soldiers in war.
This noun was coded in the feminine gender at this time.
!I had no way to get out."
A situation of suffering or indisposition.
When it is day, before being night - twilight.
In galician-portuguese and in 16th century portuguese texts, the noun 'casa' suffered reduction together with prepositions 'de', 'em', 'para', etc.
This is not the right way.
